thread.section_title: Business Breaking News | Finance & Business News | News.com.au
thread.title: Finance news you need to know today
thread.title_full: Finance news you need to know today

title: Finance news you need to know today
text:
HERE are 12 things making news in business and finance around the world today.
1. SYDNEY — The Australian dollar is higher as the focus of global markets remains on Greece as the country scrambles to prevent a debt default and a possible exit from the eurozone. At 0630 AEST on Wednesday, the local unit was trading at 77.08 US cents, up from 76.71 cents on Tuesday.
2. SYDNEY — And the Australian share market looks set to open lower, following lifts on Wall Street but falls on European markets as investors await the next move in Greece’s debt crisis. At 0645 AEST on Wednesday, the June share price index futures contract was down 30 points at 5,367.
3. BRUSSELS — Greece has asked for a fresh two-year rescue deal with the European Union in a final roll of the dice just hours before its current bailout expires and it misses a critical IMF payment.
4. BRUSSELS — Eurozone finance ministers have declined to extend Greece’s bailout, just hours before its expiry and a possible IMF default, but talks will continue on Wednesday after Athens asked for a new aid plan, officials said.
5. BRUSSELS — Inflation in the eurozone slowed to 0.2 per cent in June, with official data showing consumer prices rising just slightly despite unprecedented stimulus measures by the European Central Bank.
6. LONDON — Britain’s economy grew more than expected in the first quarter, but output was still lower compared with the end of last year, official data shows.
7. LILLE, France — Protesting French sailors have halted Eurostar trains for several hours by again blocking entry to the Channel Tunnel in Calais, with migrants using the opportunity to try to break into stationary vehicles.
8. PARIS — Uber France and two of its bosses will go on trial in September over the company’s allegedly “illegal” ride-booking practices, after violent protests by taxi drivers against the app.
9. LONDON — Reserve Bank governor Glenn Stevens says many emerging countries are ready for the United States to start raising interest rates and would like “lift-off” to happen sooner rather than later.
10. SEOUL — European aerospace giant Airbus has won a $A1.73 billion deal to supply air refuelling tankers to South Korea, beating US rival Boeing, Seoul’s military procurement agency says.
11. STOCKHOLM — Swedish defence and security group Saab says it has signed contracts with Sweden’s military for two submarines worth 8.6 billion kronor ($A1.37 billion).
12. NEW YORK — NBC and Televisa have severed business ties with Donald Trump, joining a chorus of protest over the mogul-turned-US presidential hopeful’s remarks about Mexican immigrants.
